articles.headline: F.D.A. Extends Avastin’s Use to Breast Cancer
articles.snippet: The F.D.A.’s decision appeared to lower the bar slightly for approval of certain cancer drugs.
articles.abstract: The F.D.A.’s decision appeared to lower the bar slightly for approval of certain cancer drugs.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration approved Genentech’s best-selling drug, Avastin, as a treatment for breast cancer, in a decision that appeared to lower the threshold somewhat for approval of certain cancer drugs.

articles.headline: Cheap Cocaine Floods Argentina, Devouring Lives
articles.snippet: A highly addictive, smokable cocaine residue called paco has caused a cycle of drug-induced street violence.
articles.abstract: A highly addictive, smokable cocaine residue called paco has caused a cycle of drug-induced street violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES  Bilma Acuña has two drug-addicted sons and roams the streets of the Ciudad Oculta slum here with a purpose: to save others from the same fate.

articles.headline: A ‘Moral Hazard’ for a Housing Bailout: Sorting the Victims From Those Who Volunteered
articles.snippet: Talk among banking executives for an epic government rescue plan is suddenly coming into fashion.
articles.abstract: Talk among banking executives for an epic government rescue plan is suddenly coming into fashion.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Over the last two decades, few industries have lobbied more ferociously or effectively than banks to get the government out of its business and to obtain freer rein for “financial innovation.”

articles.headline: Move Over, Oil, There’s Money in Texas Wind
articles.snippet: After breakneck growth the last three years, Texas has surpassed California as the top state for wind power.
articles.abstract: After breakneck growth the last three years, Texas has surpassed California as the top state for wind power.
articles.lead_paragraph: SWEETWATER, Tex.  The wind turbines that recently went up on Louis Brooks’s ranch are twice as high as the Statue of Liberty, with blades that span as wide as the wingspan of a jumbo jet. More important from his point of view, he is paid $500 a month apiece to permit 78 of them on his land, with 76 more on the way.

articles.headline: 2 Plans and Many Questions on the Uninsured
articles.snippet: The Democratic candidates have not provided enough detail about their health plans to enable more than guesswork about how they might influence consumers.
articles.abstract: The Democratic candidates have not provided enough detail about their health plans to enable more than guesswork about how they might influence consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA  Brandy Coons is what health economists call a free rider.

articles.headline: Stimulus Plan Aids Buyers of High-Priced Homes
articles.snippet: In the higher-priced regions of the country hit hardest by the flagging real estate market, the economic stimulus package President Bush signed into law last week could make a big difference.
articles.abstract: In the higher-priced regions of the country hit hardest by the flagging real estate market, the economic stimulus package President Bush signed into law last week could make a big difference.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Elizabeth and Ben Kilgore are back in the real estate market. All it took was a little-publicized section of the economic stimulus package President Bush signed into law last week that lowered the borrowing cost of buying a more expensive home.

articles.headline: Bond Insurer Plans a Split to Protect Ratings
articles.snippet: Ambac Financial Group plans to split itself in two and raise $3 billion, a person who has seen the plan said on Friday. The move could help restore confidence in the credit markets.
articles.abstract: Ambac Financial Group plans to split itself in two and raise $3 billion, a person who has seen the plan said on Friday. The move could help restore confidence in the credit markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ambac Financial Group, the embattled bond insurance company, plans to split itself in two in a bid to safeguard its top credit ratings and avert losses on securities that it guarantees for big banks.

articles.headline: Ahhh, the Seductive Fragrance of Molecules Under Patent
articles.snippet: The innovative scents of patented molecules are crucial to enticing consumers to buy the 600 or so new perfumes introduced every year.
articles.abstract: The innovative scents of patented molecules are crucial to enticing consumers to buy the 600 or so new perfumes introduced every year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Its scent is reminiscent of a mixture of a just-picked apple and a rose in its prime. But to the Takasago International Corporation, which manufactures this synthetic material, it smells even sweeter.

articles.headline: No Longer in Race, Richardson Is a Man Pursued
articles.snippet: Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico is being aggressively courted by the remaining Democratic candidates.
articles.abstract: Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico is being aggressively courted by the remaining Democratic candidates.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA FE, N.M.  Lots of people are calling Gov. Bill Richardson these days, “just to check in.”

articles.headline: Ominous Signs Remain in City Run by Iraqis
articles.snippet: Basra’s experiment in self-rule is occurring under relatively optimal conditions, yet the city remains deeply troubled.
articles.abstract: Basra’s experiment in self-rule is occurring under relatively optimal conditions, yet the city remains deeply troubled.
articles.lead_paragraph: BASRA, Iraq  This southern port city has been, in effect, on its own since September, when British forces here moved to the outskirts, yielding authority to local leaders. British and American officials say Basra’s experiment in self-rule could serve as a model for Iraq’s future, but if so  many locals and outside advisers say  that future remains dark.

articles.headline: Putin’s Iron Grip on Russia Suffocates Opponents
articles.snippet: Behind a facade of democracy in Russia lies a centralized authority that is not reluctant to swat down challengers.
articles.abstract: Behind a facade of democracy in Russia lies a centralized authority that is not reluctant to swat down challengers.
articles.lead_paragraph: NIZHNY NOVGOROD, Russia  Shortly before parliamentary elections in December, foremen fanned out across the sprawling GAZ vehicle factory here, pulling aside assembly-line workers and giving them an order: vote for President Vladimir V. Putin’s party or else. They were instructed to phone in after they left their polling places. Names would be tallied, defiance punished.

articles.headline: Somber Clinton Soldiers On as the Horizon Darkens
articles.snippet: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has not given up, but she no longer exudes the supreme confidence that was once her trademark.
articles.abstract: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has not given up, but she no longer exudes the supreme confidence that was once her trademark.
articles.lead_paragraph: To her longtime friends, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton sounds unusually philosophical on the phone these days. She rarely uses phrases like “when I’m president” anymore. Somber at times, determined at others, she talks to aides and confidants about the importance of focusing on a good day’s work. No drapes are being measured in her mind’s eye, they say.

articles.headline: Once Immune, Utah Is Feeling Economic Dip
articles.snippet: The state’s unexpectedly sharp economic knock is a reminder of how global and local are intertwined.
articles.abstract: The state’s unexpectedly sharp economic knock is a reminder of how global and local are intertwined.
articles.lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY  In the economic boom that thundered through Utah over the last few years, many people saw a kind of perfect chemistry at work.

articles.headline: A Capitalist Jolt for Charity
articles.snippet: Can business extend the reach of nonprofits? To help serve its philanthropic mission, a social business tries to profit.
articles.abstract: Can business extend the reach of nonprofits? To help serve its philanthropic mission, a social business tries to profit.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN the summer of 2005, Miles Gilburne and Nina Zolt had long talks over dinner in their Washington home about what to do next. For more than six years, Mr. Gilburne, a former AOL executive, and his wife, Ms. Zolt, a former lawyer, had supported a philanthropy that used books and online tools to enhance skills of inner-city students.

articles.headline: Daring to Think Differently About Schizophrenia
articles.snippet: A new drug aimed at treating schizophrenia turns its focus away from dopamine and instead on the effects of glutamate, another powerful neurotransmitter.
articles.abstract: A new drug aimed at treating schizophrenia turns its focus away from dopamine and instead on the effects of glutamate, another powerful neurotransmitter.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORTH WALES, Pa.  SCIENTISTS who develop drugs are familiar with disappointment  brilliant theories that don’t pan out or promising compounds derailed by unexpected side effects. They are accustomed to small steps and wrong turns, to failure after failure  until, in a moment, with hard work, brainpower and a lot of luck, all those little failures turn into one big success.

articles.headline: After the War, a New Battle to Become Citizens
articles.snippet: Some immigrant members of the military have waited years for their citizenship applications to be processed.
articles.abstract: Some immigrant members of the military have waited years for their citizenship applications to be processed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite a 2002 promise from President Bush to put citizenship applications for immigrant members of the military on a fast track, some are finding themselves waiting months, or even years, because of bureaucratic backlogs. One, Sgt. Kendell K. Frederick of the Army, who had tried three times to file for citizenship, was killed by a roadside bomb in Iraq as he returned from submitting fingerprints for his application.

articles.headline: Offering Financial Calm Amid the Storm of Divorce
articles.snippet: Perhaps the easiest phase of a divorce is the court-recognized dissolution of the marriage. I keep in mind that I am an adviser who educates and empowers clients.
articles.abstract: Perhaps the easiest phase of a divorce is the court-recognized dissolution of the marriage. I keep in mind that I am an adviser who educates and empowers clients.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN I started practicing as a certified divorce financial analyst in 2004, I knew that I would use the skills I had acquired over 16 years in the financial services industry. But what I didn’t realize was that I would often feel like a therapist.
articles.byline: By CAROL E. ARNOTT; As told to ELIZABETH OLSON

articles.headline: Your Publicist Should Call My Publicist
articles.snippet: In Hollywood studios’ public relations, one team plays offense while a second plays defense.
articles.abstract: In Hollywood studios’ public relations, one team plays offense while a second plays defense.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  AT the annual Oscar nominees luncheon a few weeks ago, Frank Pierson  the writer of “Dog Day Afternoon,” the director of “A Star Is Born” and a former president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences  expressed wonderment as he sized up the room. And he wasn’t marveling at George Clooney’s smile.

articles.headline: Michelin Gives Stars, but Tokyo Turns Up Nose
articles.snippet: Food critics and magazines have questioned the guide’s choice of restaurants and ratings in its first Asia venture.
articles.abstract: Food critics and magazines have questioned the guide’s choice of restaurants and ratings in its first Asia venture.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  The Michelin guide recently ventured into Asia for the first time in its 108-year history to research and publish a Japanese-language guide to Tokyo restaurants. To gain credibility, it hired Japanese restaurant judges to work with its European experts and adapted its standards to the nation’s special culinary culture.

articles.headline: In the Drama of Britney Spears, a Show Business Fortune Is at Risk
articles.snippet: Estimates of Britney Spears’s net worth vary from $50 million to $125 million, but being a wealthy pop icon doesn’t make one impervious to financial disaster.
articles.abstract: Estimates of Britney Spears’s net worth vary from $50 million to $125 million, but being a wealthy pop icon doesn’t make one impervious to financial disaster.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Britney Spears’s klieg-lighted meltdown sent her to the psychiatric ward twice, and left her long-divorced parents, her brother, and a SWAT team of lawyers and accountants grappling with how to protect her from predatory hangers-on, from the paparazzi who dog her every move and from her own erratic behavior.
articles.byline: By David M. Halbfinger and Geraldine Fabrikant

articles.headline: Studios Are Trying to Stop DVDs From Fading to Black
articles.snippet: The victory of Sony’s new Blu-ray high-definition disc over a rival format, Toshiba’s HD DVD, masks a problem facing the studios: the overall decline of the DVD market.
articles.abstract: The victory of Sony’s new Blu-ray high-definition disc over a rival format, Toshiba’s HD DVD, masks a problem facing the studios: the overall decline of the DVD market.
articles.lead_paragraph: A winner has finally been declared in Hollywood’s high-definition DVD war. So why isn’t there more cheering?
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Matt Richtel

articles.headline: Fewer Youths Jump Behind the Wheel at 16
articles.snippet: Licenses are no longer as coveted in adolescence, as parents are more willing to be chauffeurs.
articles.abstract: Licenses are no longer as coveted in adolescence, as parents are more willing to be chauffeurs.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  For generations, driver’s licenses have been tickets to freedom for America’s 16-year-olds, prompting many to line up at motor vehicle offices the day they were eligible to apply.
articles.byline: By Mary M. Chapman and Micheline Maynard

articles.headline: Distrust of McCain Lingers Over ’05 Deal on Judges
articles.snippet: Some conservatives resent John McCain’s role in a pact that averted a vote on banning filibusters against judicial nominees.
articles.abstract: Some conservatives resent John McCain’s role in a pact that averted a vote on banning filibusters against judicial nominees.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Back in 2005, Senator John McCain of Arizona and fellow members of the so-called Gang of 14 were hailed as heroes in some quarters when they fashioned an unusual pact that averted a Senate vote on banning filibusters against judicial nominees.

articles.headline: Blogger, Sans Pajamas, Rakes Muck and a Prize
articles.snippet: Cited for its reporting on the firing of eight U.S. attorneys, the political blog Talking Points Memo became the first Internet-only news operation to win the George Polk Award.
articles.abstract: Cited for its reporting on the firing of eight U.S. attorneys, the political blog Talking Points Memo became the first Internet-only news operation to win the George Polk Award.
articles.lead_paragraph: Of the many landmarks along a journalist’s career, two are among those that stand out: winning an award and making the government back down. Last week, Joshua Micah Marshall achieved both.

articles.headline: In Painful Past, Hushed Worry About Obama
articles.snippet: Some voters are invoking the memories of the killings of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Senator Robert F. Kennedy in 1968.
articles.abstract: Some voters are invoking the memories of the killings of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Senator Robert F. Kennedy in 1968.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS  There is a hushed worry on the minds of many supporters of Senator Barack Obama, echoing in conversations from state to state, rally to rally: Will he be safe?

articles.headline: Game Maker in $2 Billion Bid for Rival
articles.snippet: A bid by Electronic Arts for Take-Two Interactive would further a wave of consolidation in the gaming industry.
articles.abstract: A bid by Electronic Arts for Take-Two Interactive would further a wave of consolidation in the gaming industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Electronic Arts, the video gaming giant, made an unsolicited $2 billion bid on Sunday for rival Take-Two Interactive, publisher of the Grand Theft Auto franchise, a deal that would further a wave of consolidation in the rapidly growing industry.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Seth Schiesel

articles.headline: Rising Inflation Creates Unease in Middle East
articles.snippet: Inflation, caused in part by the skyrocketing price of oil, is pushing many ordinary people toward poverty even as oil money stimulates economic growth in the gulf.
articles.abstract: Inflation, caused in part by the skyrocketing price of oil, is pushing many ordinary people toward poverty even as oil money stimulates economic growth in the gulf.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan  Even as it enriches Arab rulers, the recent oil-price boom is helping to fuel an extraordinary rise in the cost of food and other basic goods that is squeezing this region’s middle class and setting off strikes, demonstrations and occasional riots from Morocco to the Persian Gulf.

articles.headline: Adobe Blurs Line Between PC and Web
articles.snippet: A software developer has created a new system that will power potentially tens of thousands of applications that merge the Internet and the PC.
articles.abstract: A software developer has created a new system that will power potentially tens of thousands of applications that merge the Internet and the PC.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  On sabbatical in 2001 from Macromedia, Kevin Lynch, a software developer, was frustrated that he could not get to his Web data when he was off the Internet and annoyed that he could not get to his PC data when he was traveling.

articles.headline: Born Irish, but With Illegal Parents
articles.snippet: George-Jordan Dimbo, born in Ireland 11 years ago to illegal immigrant parents, may soon be living in Africa.
articles.abstract: George-Jordan Dimbo, born in Ireland 11 years ago to illegal immigrant parents, may soon be living in Africa.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBLIN  Cork-born and proud of it, George-Jordan Dimbo is top to toe the Irish lad. He studies Gaelic, eats rashers, plays hurling, prays to the saints, papers his walls with parochial school awards, and spends Saturdays at the telly watching Dustin the Turkey, a wisecracking puppet, mock the powerful.
